name: N-(9-fluorenylmethoxycarbonyloxy)succinimide
Reason: 1-ethylpiperazine-2,3-dione has a melting point around 106°C. The presence of two carbonyl groups generally increases the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, which can raise it by approximately +10°C each. However, 1-ethyl substitution tends to lower the melting point compared to piperazine, as it creates a more asymmetric structure, reducing the crystal lattice stability, which might decrease the melting point by approximately -10°C. Summing up these changes: Piperazine base (+106°C), two carbonyl groups (+20°C), and one ethyl group (-10°C). Additionally, the fluorenylmethoxycarbonyloxy group introduces a rigid structure and additional molecular weight, estimated at +20°C. The methoxy group introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at +10°C. The carbonyl group introduces additional rigid structures, estimated at +10°C. The fluorenyl group introduces additional pi-pi interactions, estimated at +20°C. The methoxy group introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at +10°C. The carbonyl group introduces additional rigid structures, estimated at +10°C. The fluorenyl group introduces additional pi-pi interactions, estimated at +20°C.
